intro: Echinochloa crus-galli var. microstachya, commonly known as barnyard grass, is a highly invasive annual grass species native to temperate regions of the Americas. It is characterized by its flat, ribbed leaves and spikelets that are often clustered in dense, panicle-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in a prostrate or upright manner, depending on environmental conditions, and can reach heights of up to 1 meter. It thrives in disturbed soils and is commonly found in agricultural fields, roadsides, and wetlands. Due to its rapid growth and competitive nature, it is considered a major weed in many parts of the world.
